content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/">   <channel rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/1893/18160">     <title>STORRE Community: This community contains ePrints produced by Information Services\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd staff.</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/1893/18160</link>     <description>This community contains ePrints produced by Information Services\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd staff.</description>     <items>       <rdf:Seq>         <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://hdl.handle.net/1893/18203" />         <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://hdl.handle.net/1893/18202" />         <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://hdl.handle.net/1893/18185" />       </rdf:Seq>     </items>     <dc:date>2015-03-12T09:51:15Z</dc:date>   </channel>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/1893/18203">     <title>Digging for victory: finding difficult information</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/1893/18203</link>     <description>Title: Digging for victory: finding difficult information Authors: Guite, Candace Abstract: First paragraph: Digging for victory was an all-day workshop organised by the East of England ISG and held in Norwich\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds new flagship Archive Centre on 26 April 2006. The entire collection at the Archive Centre has recently received designated status from the Museum, Libraries and Archives Council (MlLA) and delegates were able to view a selection of the Archive's treasures during the lunch-break.</description>     <dc:date>2006-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/1893/18202">     <title>It's a virtual life: exploring social networks</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/1893/18202</link>     <description>Title: It's a virtual life: exploring social networks Authors: Guite, Candace Abstract: As information librarians we are focused on communication and the need to keep in touch with our user communities. Across a wide age range in the UK, nearly half the population (24 million adults) use one or more social networking sites. Information producers, librarians and users have had to come to terms, in their different ways, with the challenges posed by the exponential growth in social networking sites and the opportunities that Web 2.0 provides. The East of England ISG Spring Meeting on \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdlt's a Virtual Life: exploring social networks\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd discussed the issues and examined experiences of using Web 2.0. lt was held on 17 April 2008 at BT's Adastral Park in lpswich. Several of the papers are available on the web at www.cilipeoe.org.uk/archives/isg_l7thapril.shtml</description>     <dc:date>2008-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://hdl.handle.net/1893/18185">     <title>He who pays the piper: shifting Scottish legal landscapes</title>     <link>http://hdl.handle.net/1893/18185</link>     <description>Title: He who pays the piper: shifting Scottish legal landscapes Authors: Guite, Candace Abstract: If Scotland votes 'Yes' to the question 'Should Scotland be an independent country?' how will its relationship change with the remainder of the UK? A 'yes' vote will have huge financial, political and legal implications. This article, written by Candace Guite, considers the current role of the UK Supreme Court in Scotland, the recent conflict (to which the title alludes) and it reflects on Scotland's potential international status. The UK Government has argued that it would be regarded as the continuator state and an independent Scotland would be a successor state, and so, in the event of a 'yes' vote Scotland would have to re-apply for entry to the European Union and the United Nations. However, there are arguments to support the alternative option, that Scotland could be regarded as a co-equal successor state with England, and thus would retain EU and UN membership.</description>     <dc:date>2013-09-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date>   </item> </rdf:RDF>
